Lionstring Hero Review - Empires and Puzzles Strategy Guide

Lionstring stitches together a unique kit of healing theft and dodge at Very Fast speed. While his stats may be fraying by 2025 standards, this Astral Elf Dressmaker can still weave a nightmare for opponents in 4-Star tournaments.
Lionstring: The Very Fast Tailor Who Stitches Up Healers

Lionstring arrived in March 2024 as part of the glitzy Astral Summon, bringing a touch of haute couture to the battlefield. As a Nature (Green) Epic Wizard, he stands out not for brute force, but for his blistering

mana speed and a utility belt that includes dodging and petty theft (of healing, that is). In a world of hulking barbarians and cosmic dragons, Lionstring is just a dressmaker with a measuring tape and a dream—and surprisingly, that's often enough to ruin an opponent's day in 4-Star tournaments.

Lionstring’s visual design is delightfully distinct. He appears to be a cosmic tailor or dressmaker, draped in fabric that swirls like the night sky. He wields needles and measuring tape rather than a sword or staff, giving him a non-threatening appearance that belies his annoying skill set. It’s a refreshing break from the "angry warrior screaming at the sky" trope. He looks like he’s about to critique your defense team’s outfit coordination before dodging your attacks.
Lionstring’s stats were solid for early 2024 but face a steep uphill battle in late 2025.
(released Dec 2025), Lionstring feels a bit threadbare.

Breca boasts over 100 more points in Attack and Defense, and a massive 200+ point lead in Health.
To keep Lionstring relevant, you absolutely need to Limit Break him (LB1 and likely LB2). Without the stat boost, he risks being one-shot by modern snipers before he can even lift his needle.
"Cloth of Constellations" is a skill that thrives on disruption rather than destruction.
speed, Lionstring charges in just 6.5 tiles (6 tiles with a small mana boost). This allows him to fire early and often, setting up his defensive buffs before the enemy can properly engage.
to himself and nearby allies is his most potent ability. While it only lasts 2 turns, the Very Fast speed means you can keep it active frequently. It forces enemies to gamble with their specials.
Stealing 50% of healing is a niche but hilarious mechanic. It turns the enemy's healers into partial batteries for your team. It’s particularly rude against heal-over-time (HoT) heroes.
The 245% damage to the target (and minor to nearby) is negligible by 2025 standards. Don't rely on him to kill; rely on him to annoy.
. With a level 11 Mana Troop (or even lower with costume/emblem bonuses if applicable, though he has no costume), he hits the 6-tile breakpoint easily.

245% of ~684 Attack is roughly 1,675 damage value (before defense). Against modern defenses with 1000+ defense, this will likely result in "chip damage"—perhaps 200-300 actual damage. He is not a killer.
The 45% Dodge effectively gives his team (well, 3 of them) nearly a coin-flip chance to ignore huge hits like
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Astral Elf family kit is designed for survival and disruption, making them slippery targets.

The chance to dispel a buff from an attacker (50% for 1 hero, 70% for 2) is a fantastic passive defense. If an enemy with Attack Up hits Lionstring, they might lose that buff instantly. It’s a subtle punishment that disrupts combo chains.

This is a double-edged sword. It prevents Lionstring from being sniped out of existence (sharing the blow with tankier allies), but it also means he transmits damage to his neighbors. In 4-star tournaments where Alpha Aether snipers are rampant, this usually helps him survive that crucial first hit.
(Note: Data sources vary, but Astral Elves typically resist accuracy-affecting ailments). This ensures his special skill—which "never misses"—is truly reliable.

. This stacks thematically with his special skill. For the first 6 turns, he has a passive chance to dodge specials. If his special skill is also active, he becomes incredibly elusive, frustrating enemies who just want to pin him down.
Upon release, Lionstring was hailed as a top-tier 4-star, often compared to a mini-Kadilen (Costume) due to the dodge. He was a staple in 4-Star Buff Booster tournaments.
The damage numbers have fallen off a cliff. 245% damage is now what some healers do. However,
is a mechanic that ages gracefully. Even if he does zero damage, making a teammate dodge a kill-shot is valuable.

in specific niches: 4-Star Tournaments (especially Rush and Buff Booster) and War Cleanup teams. He is no longer a general-purpose raid hero, but in restricted formats, his speed and utility still shine.
As of late 2025, Lionstring does not have a costume.
He must rely on his base kit and Limit Breaks to keep up with the stat inflation of newer heroes.
Lionstring is a support hero disguised as a wizard. His damage is secondary; staying alive to cast Dodge is primary.
Maximizes his survivability. With "Share Damage" and low base stats, he needs every point of armor to avoid being the weak link.
His special skill hit becomes even softer, essentially just a tickle.
Tries to make his Very Fast hit count for something, utilizing the Wizard Jinx talent for extra damage.
He becomes dangerously fragile and may die before firing his second loop of Dodge.
path is recommended. You bring him for the Dodge and the Cure-Steal, not the damage.
Very Fast mana allows him to dictate the pace of the match.
Dodge is one of the strongest defensive buffs in the game.
Stealing healing is an excellent counter to heavy healer teams, effectively functioning as a "reverse heal."
Reliable against Dodge or Blind heavy teams.
severely outclassed by late 2025 heroes in raw numbers.
The buffs/debuffs only last 2 turns. You must keep firing to maintain them.
He effectively contributes zero offensive pressure against modern tanks.
His Dodge is a buff, making him vulnerable to dispellers (like Sabina or Melendor) who can strip his protection instantly.
His Dodge counts as a buff, and his speed allows him to stack it quickly.
While already Very Fast, Rush makes him even more oppressive, though his relative speed advantage is diminished.
Good for protecting a team of leftovers against a partially killed enemy defense.
Lionstring is a "protector" flank. He should sit next to your tank or your key glass cannon to keep them safe.
Goldie reflects ailments, Lionstring provides Dodge, and Caedmon cleanses/dispels. A very annoying defensive core for tournaments.
Proteus stops mana, Lionstring steals any passive healing, and Gato provides immunity. Good for controlling boss fights.
(Sabina, Melendor, Mist) are his worst nightmare. If they strip his Dodge, he is just a squishy elf with a needle.
can also dispel his buffs easily.
. Don't pair him with another Dodge hero (like C. Kadilen in War) as the buffs will overwrite each other, wasting efficiency.

Lionstring is an excellent pull. He offers a pseudo-5-star ability (Dodge) at a 4-star cost. Level him immediately for your tournament teams and War depth. He will save your team more often than you realize.

You likely have 5-star heroes who do this better (Constance, Ukkonen, etc.). However, Lionstring is still a king in the 4-star arena. If you care about tournament loot, he is worth the emblems and LB1. Save the Alpha Aethers (LB2) for heroes with more timeless stats unless you are a tournament specialist.
When released, the community was pleasantly surprised.
"This guy is the F2P 5* from this portal," one player noted, highlighting his high-value skill set for a 4-star.
"Valeria cries in the corner," joked another, noting how Lionstring's healing steal outclassed older mechanics.
"Not so many 4* Very Fast heroes. Dodge, share dmg with others, steal of the healing - seems like a nice tank for tourneys."

Lionstring is a prime example of "utility over power." He won't win any arm-wrestling contests against the steroid-fueled heroes of late 2025, but he doesn't have to. He just has to be faster than them. With his ability to weave a protective cloak of stars around your team before the enemy can blink, he remains a staple of the discerning player's 4-star roster.
A fragile but incredibly useful utility hero who remains a top pick for 4-star tournaments despite aging stats.
